title.rendered: Find Rooms For Rent In Mexico City

content.rendered:
With Roomi’s guide to Mexico City, you can learn all about what living in the city will be like. Find rooms for rent in Mexico City, and discover how you can get around with ease!

Related: 15 Best Things To Do In Mexico City

Getting to know Mexico City

When you move to a new city, you want to explore every inch of it as soon as possible. However, given how expansive Mexico City is, that might take a while! The city is divided into 16 boroughs, which make it easier to navigate. Getting around the city is easy, thanks to the abundance of public transportation options, although locals love using the metro.

With plenty of eateries, nightclubs, and malls, you’ll have a lot of fun exploring the area.

Related: Is It Time For You To Move To Another City?

Finding rooms for rent in Mexico City

Find Rooms For Rent In Mexico City

Living in Mexico City may be more expensive than anywhere else in Mexico, but it is still less than the national living cost in the US. The average rent in Mexico City is quite reasonable, but when trying to find rooms for rent in Mexico City, ensure that you get one that is close to your workplace to avoid too much traffic.

Related: How to Declutter When you Share an Apartment

Top neighborhoods in Mexico City

  • Roma: Experience the best of the city’s night life in Roma. Here, you can not only find plenty of entertainment options, but also art museums and trendy café’s. Often referred to as the hipster neighborhood in Mexico City, you won’t have any trouble finding a fun evening.
  • Copilco: Can’t start your day without a dose of caffeine? Living in Copilco, you won’t be too far away from the nearest trendy café. Snag a room in this neighborhood, along with excellent eateries to visit with your friends!
  • San Rafael: If you’re looking for cheap rooms for rent in Mexico City, this is the neighborhood for you. Close to the heart of the city, but without any of the noise and disturbance, this neighborhood is often referred to as the “artsy” side of town.

Related: 5 Ways To Save Money For Your Next Vacation

Average rent in Mexico City

University life in Mexico City

Compared to the rest of North America or Europe, living in Mexico City is much more affordable. Students don’t have to worry about high tuition costs or living expenses, and can enjoy fun student life in the city. Finding affordable rooms for rent in Mexico City on a student’s budget is easy, especially when you have someone to share with!

Mexico City boasts of some of the top universities in Mexico, with the Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM) being one of the top universities in Latin America.

Top universities in the city:

  • Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM)
  • Instituto Politécnico Nacional (IPN)
  • Universidad Panamericana (UP)
  • Universidad Anáhuac México

How transit friendly is Mexico City?

While the city is vast, driving is not the best way to get around, even for tourists. Luckily, residents of Mexico City enjoy plenty of public transit options, which connect you to anywhere you want to visit in the city.

1. Walkability

Mexico City may be vast, but its neighborhoods are quite walkable. No matter where you find rooms for rent in Mexico City, you’ll be able to enjoy an evening stroll around your neighborhood as you run your errands.

2. Roads/traffic

Among other things, Mexico City is known for its severe traffic and congestion problems. Although new road projects are underway, driving in the city is often an exercise in patience, as you would need to stall in traffic for what seems like hours. If you’re new to the city, it may be difficult for you to navigate through the city during a traffic rush. Hence, it is best to stick to the public transit options.

3. Taxis

From Uber’s to regular old taxi services, you won’t find a shortage of taxis in Mexico City. There are some dedicated taxi services that will get you to and from the airport as well. Wherever you want to go, a taxi is just a call or a click away.

4. Public transportation

Most residents rely on public transportation to get around the city. It is quick, easy to access, and most importantly, keeps you away from the traffic on the road. When exploring Mexico City you have plenty of public transit options, from using the metro – which is the most used transportation in the city – to opting for regular buses, metro buses, or trolleybuses. To get to the tourist spots, you can either go for the light rail or the Turibus, a double-decker hop-in and hop-out bus service that takes you sightseeing around the city.

To plan your trip, don’t forget to head to Via DF to get a better idea of the bus routes around the city.

5. Airports

The Benito Juarez International Airport is the closest airport to the city and the most preferred option when you’re flying in and out of Mexico City. The recently converted Toluca International Airport is located about 31 miles from Mexico City and is a great option for those who are looking for low-cost domestic flights.

6. Cycling

If you’re traveling shorter distances, then biking is probably one of the best ways to get around the city. You can not only wade through the streets faster but also avoid getting stuck in traffic jams. Mexico City has a public bike-share system, known as the ecobici, that allows you to rent bikes whenever you want.

Population in Mexico City

Since the 1950s, the city’s population has grown by 544%. Currently, Mexico City is one of the most populated cities in North America with 21.7 million residents as of 2021. It has the largest number of US citizen population outside of the USA.

Historical/Cultural Spots

The city has no shortage of historical and cultural spots. Mexico City has a rich history and is home to several museums and archaeological sites. When visiting this city, your itinerary will be full of must-visit historical landmarks in the city.

  • Zocalo, a historical walking site in the city.
  • Basilica de Santa Maria de Guadalupe, built to honor the city’s patron saint.
  • Zona Arqueológica de Teotihuacan Estacionamiento Puerta 5, one of the best preserved sites of ancient Mesoamerican civilisation.

D’you know what else Roomi does outside of helping its readers find a room for rent in Mexico City? With our ever-increasing lists of rooms and roommates across the world, we’ll help you find your perfect match!

DOWNLOAD THE APP NOW!
